abstract: Republican senators are pushing to include a provision in a 2012 military authorization bill that would require non-American Al Qaeda suspects accused of plotting attacks to be held in military custody, even if they are arrested in the United States, which the Obama administration opposes; move is indicative of Congressional Republicans' hardening stance against the use of the civilian criminal justice system for terrorist suspects.
snippet: Congressional Republicans increasingly rejected any use of the civilian criminal justice system for handling cases involving Al Qaeda.
lead_paragraph: Congressional Republicans increasingly rejected any use of the civilian criminal justice system for handling cases involving Al Qaeda.

headline.main: G.O.P. Pushes Military Custody for Terror Suspects
headline.print_headline: G.O.P. Takes Hard Line in Pushing Military Trials for All Terrorism Suspects
headline.seo: Republicans Push Military Trials for Terrorism Suspects
